resource.name: NIJ's Recidivism Challenge Training Dataset
resource.description:
Terms of Use

Please read the terms of use below.

The National Institute of Justice (NIJ) adheres to codes of conduct that are generally accepted in higher education and scientific research for the exchange and proper use of knowledge and information.

These data are distributed under the following terms of use. By continuing past this point to the data retrieval process, you signify your agreement to comply with the requirements stated below:

Privacy and Confidentiality of Data

Any intentional identification of a individuals or unauthorized disclosure of his or her confidential information violates the promise of confidentiality given to the providers of the information. Therefore, users of data agree:

•                 To use these datasets solely for research or statistical purposes and not for investigation of specific individuals
•                 To make no use of the identity of any individual discovered inadvertently, and to advise NIJ of any such discovery (NIJRecidivismChallenge@usdoj.gov)

Federal law and regulations require that research data collected by the U.S. Department of Justice or by its grantees and contractors may only be used for research or statistical purposes. The applicable laws and regulations may be found in the United States Code, 34 USC Section 10231(a), the Code of Federal Regulations, 28 CFR 22, and 62 F.R. 35044 (June 27, 1997) (The Federal Confidentiality Order). Accordingly, any intentional identification or disclosure of a person or establishment may violate federal law as well as the assurances of confidentiality given to the providers of the information. Therefore, users of this data must agree to abide by these regulations and understand that NIJ may report any potential violation to the appropriate entities within the U.S. Department of Justice.

resource.name: NCVS Select - Personal Victimization
resource.description: Contains personal crime victimizations. Personal crimes include rape and sexual assault, robbery, aggravated and simple assault, and personal theft/larceny (purse-snatching/pocket picking).  Persons that did not report a personal crime victimization are not included on this file. Victimizations that took place outside of the United States are excluded from this file.
columns_description: Specifies whether the crime was reported to police
Classification of respondent residence based on the Office of Management and Budget definition of metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs)
Specifies whether victims received any help or advice from victim service agencies
Respondent age on the last day of the month before the interview
Specifies whether bodily hurt or damage was sustained by a victim as the result of criminal victimization
Specifies whether incident is a series crime
Year and quarter data was collected
Location of household based on BJS geography definitions, starting 2020 Q1
Violent crime excluding simple assault includes rape or sexual assault, robbery, aggravated assault
The size range for the place in which the housing unit is located
Classification of respondent relationship to the offender for crimes involving direct contact
Aggregate type of crime; violent crime includes all rape, sexual assault, robbery, assault
Respondent level of education, starting 2003 Q1
Specifies whether a weapon was present during the victimization
Specifies the type of bodily hurt or damage sustained by respondent
Specifies whether respondent received medical treatment for injuries from crime
Total income of all members of the household for the 12 months preceding the interview. Categories  available from 1993-2020 with imputed data, starting 2015 Q1.
Region of respondent residence. The states have been divided into four groups or census regions, starting 1995 Q1.

domain_metadata.value: 061: Criminal Justice Statistical Program (Bureau of Justice Statistics) (BJS)

resource.name: NCVS Select - Household Victimization
resource.description: Contains property crime victimizations. Property crimes include burglary, theft, motor vehicle theft, and vandalism. Households that did not report a property crime victimization are not included on this file. Victimizations that took place outside of the United States are excluded from this file.
columns_description: Region of respondent residence. The states have been divided into four groups or census regions, starting 1995 Q1.
The total number of people residing in the household, including those under age 12
Classification of respondent residence based on the Office of Management and Budget definition of metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs)
Aggregate type of crime; property crime includes burglary/trespassing, motor-vehicle theft, theft.
Specifies whether the crime was reported to police
Specifies whether victims received any help or advice from victim service agencies
The size range for the place in which the housing unit is located
Location of household based on BJS geography definitions, starting 2020 Q1
Respondent age on the last day of the month before the interview
Total income of all members of the household for the 12 months preceding the interview. Categories  available from 1993-2020 with imputed data, starting 2015 Q1.
Year and quarter data was collected

domain_metadata.value: 061: Criminal Justice Statistical Program (Bureau of Justice Statistics) (BJS)
